newsitem.title: ETHIOPIA: Ethiopian suspects died of torture, court told.
newsitem.headline: Ethiopian suspects died of torture, court told.

text.p: Three teenagers bled to death from "inhuman" torture after being arrested in 1978 for the attempted murder of a government official, an Ethiopian court heard on Tuesday.

A prosecution witness told the court in the capital Addis Ababa that 35 people were arrested suspected of attempting to murder Captain Legesse Asfaw, a top official in the Marxist "Dergue" regime of Mengistu Haile Mariam, who was ousted from power in May 1991.
The witness was one of those detained by Mengistu's revolutionary guards and was released in 1983 after languishing in prison for nearly five years.
"All of us were subjected to inhuman and severe torture at the interrogation centre," the witness said.

"Three of the suspects, who were in their teens, died of bleeding after the torture -- one was sleeping near me and died as I was trying to dress his wounds ..." said the witness, aged 65 and a former teacher, who cannot be identified under court orders.
He was testifying at the trial of 71 former Dergue officials accused of genocide and crimes against humanity. They face the death penalty if found guilty.
Twenty-five of the accused, including Mengistu who is exiled in Zimbabwe, are being tried in absentia.
The witness said he lived in Disrict 24 of Addis Ababa and was a friend and neighbour of Legesse's family.
He said he was jailed because Legesse's mother told her son the witness was plotting with other members of an opposition Marxist group to kill Legesse.

The Ethiopian government has charged a total of 5,198 with war crimes, aggravated homicide and genocide. Of these, 1,200 are suspected of involvement in Mengistu's 1970s "Red Terror" against opponents.
The trial was adjourned until Thursday.
